data.title: Update the jsconfig.json schema descriptions
data.body:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/172399/13945230/ec5e3b0a-f00b-11e5-853c-676856fed4d5.png)

Remove
- locale (VS only currently)
- diagnostics (only for down-level compiling)
- maproot (only used for down-level compiling, and if we add maproot then we would have to add sourceMap, inlineSourceMap, etc)

data.title: VS Code does not recognize the currently active .net run-time.
data.body:
When I use the VSCode command palette `dnx: run command` to execute my .NET Core C# console app, I'm given the error:

> current runtime target framework is not compatible.  
> Current runtime target framework: 'DNX,Version=v4.5.1 (dnx451)'

This error is non-sensical, because I have the correct version selected globally.  I noticed a [Stackoverflow post where somebody else is experiencing the same problem](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/34708489/system-invalidoperationexception-the-current-runtime-target-framework-is-not-co).
- VSCode Version: 0.10.11
- OS Version: Windows 10 Home

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open new cmd prompt, and change to folder where I have a .NET Core C# console app.
2. Execute `dnvm list` to confirm that `1.0.0-rc1-update1 coreclr x86` is selected globally.
3. From the same cmd prompt, launch `code .`
4. Use the VSCode command palette to execute `dnx run`

At this point an error is produced, as already described.

data.title: Is darwinBundleDocumentTypes is out of date?
data.body: I noticed the `config` variable in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/4483, there are some built-in extensions that contributes file extensions but aren't added here. Not sure exactly what this drives, but maybe it should be generated automatically?

data.title: File closes on save when working via gvfs

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:  0.10.10 (git 5b5f4db87c10345b9d5c8d0bed745bcad4533135)
- OS Version:Ubuntu 15.10, gvfs 1.24.2 (the os is freshly installed)

I'm mounting another linux machine via `gvfs-mount` to edit files. After several saves, the file closes and I have to reopen it.  The file was opened in the "working files" area of the explorer tree. 

I don't see any disconnection of the mounted connection. `dmesg` has no messages.

Steps to Reproduce:
(On another Ubuntu 15.10 machine, I can reproduce the issue exactly)
1. Save the file several (about 5 or more) times ("force saving" aka hammering `CTRL+S` or the save menu does **not** reproduce this issue)

data.title: Feature request: install local extensions
data.body:
Now can only install extensions into 
- **Windows** %USERPROFILE%.vscode\extensions
- **Mac** $HOME/.vscode/extensions
- **Linux** $HOME/.vscode/extensions

I think it is more convenient if can install an extension in local project, then every project can have different extensions.

data.title: Please allow javascript editor in html script block
data.body: When we write HTML file, sometimes we want to write javascript directly in that page. So vscode should inject javascript editor between `<script>` tag

data.title: No hotkey is available for navigating the call stack
data.body: The latest update boasts "All debug actions are keyboard accessible", but it seems there's still no keybinding endpoint for navigating up and down the call stack.

data.title: Getting error message when launching app from command prompt with "disable-extension" argument.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Launch an app from command prompt without any command line argument.
   >code-alpha
2. Open any folder which contains C# code.
3. Verify installed extensions for C#, PS, GO etc. should work fine.
4. Verify there should not be any error message. 
5. Close app and re-launch it from command prompt with disable-extension argument.
   >code-alpha --disable-extension
6. Verify app behavior and configuration changes.

Actual:
1. Getting error message Like: "Cannot convert undefined or null to object"

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13939789/40f63f90-ef95-11e5-93a7-a2b75089d8f6.png)
1. There is no changes in app behavior or configuration. 
   a. Default setting is not changing at all.
   b. Linter is working as it was working before re-launch.
   c. Debugger is working as it was working before re-launch.
   d. Intellisense is working as it was working before re-launch.

Expected: There should not be any error message.

Clarification: What are the changes user should expect when launching app with --disable-extension argument.

data.title: [Uninstall] When user uninstall an app then system should delete all the VS code references, files and directories.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Install VSCode alpha build.
2. Open app to verify successfully installation.
3. Close app and uninstall 
4. Verify "Microsoft VS Code Alpha" directory under "C:\Program Files (x86)\"

Actual: "Microsoft VS Code Alpha" is present under "C:\program Files(x86)\"
Expected: All directories, files and references should be deleted when user performed uninstall operation.

data.title: can't navigate javascript with manual namespaces
Improve File Association feature (status bar)
data.body:
I like this new feature... I have some suggested improvements. Open to discussion of course :) 

Let's take a simple use case. I have a file `.babelrc`. This file is a JSON file. VS Code detects it as Plain Text. I click in the bottom right to change it to `JSON`. I see that there are two options "Auto Detect" and "Configure file association for .babelrc". 

I try "Auto Detect". The file is still Plain Text. (1) I would expect Auto Detect to intelligently figure out I am using JSON. 

I try "Configure file association for .babelrc." I am taken to settings.json. A popup explains that I may need to restart. I don't see any instructions nor do I know where to look. (2) I am not sure how to proceed. 

I try setting `.babelrc` to JSON. This works as expected. I close the file and come back to it. Its back to Plain Text. (3) I would have expected it to stay JSON. 

Couple of ideas. For (1) can we intelligently figure out what the file is? We could start with a JSON file or other common configuration files. Also, what is "Auto Detect" supposed to do? It seems like we're already auto detecting every single file. We could consider dropping it. 

(2) We should provide some prompt for settings. Even a navigation and highlighting of the settings command that needs to be configured would be helpful. This could be similar to what @alexandrudima did for keybindings. As it stands, I need to know to trigger suggest to know what to type. This isn't obvious, especially for new users. 

(3) What if VS Code saved a file's association automatically. For example if I set .babelrc to JSON, I would expect there to be an association and never have to do it again (at least for the workspace I am in). 

Just some thoughts.

// @chrisdias

data.title: Copying a file from Windows explorer into same directory in VS Code removes all code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a project folder
2. Right click a file -> 'Reveal in Explorer'
3. Drag the file from Windows Explorer to the same directory it is already in
4. Click 'Replace'
5. Refresh the folder in VS Code
6. Go back to the file

Actual:
The file is now empty

Expected:
It would not overwrite the file with no data

data.title: translations: Single quotes are replaced by double quotes in German translation
data.body:
Single quotes are replaced by double quotes in German translation:

```
"Cannot find runtime '{0}' on PATH.",
"Die Laufzeit \"{0}\" wurde in \"PATH\" nicht gefunden.",
"No se encuentra el runtime '{0}' en PATH.",
```

Is this intentional?

In addition the German translation seems to introduce quotes as for PATH above.
Is this intentional?

data.title: [Windows] Gettiing error "Cannot convert undefined or null to object"  while adding .Js or .cs file.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows10

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  Launch app and open any folder.
2. Try to add .js or .cs file by clicking on + sign.
3. Verify app behavior.
4. Try to add other file like go, css, ts and verify app behavior.

Actual: Getting error "Cannot convert undefined or null to object" when adding .js or .cs file.
Expected: It should not throw any error while adding .js or .cs file.

Note: I tried the same steps on MAC and it is working fine. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17735796/13932862/7a1fd8ae-ef67-11e5-9920-ede5e4781ea4.png)

data.title: Expose paths constants in API
data.body:
From mail, from Erich:

> A nit, it currently only works in the `stable` product:
> 
> privateextensionsPath: string= path.join(os.homedir(), '.vscode', 'extensions');
> 
> we should provide some API/constants for the product specific paths so that extensions do not have
> to do path-math and getting it wrong.

data.title: Clicking error indicator multiple times displays fewer errors each click
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 0.10.12-alpha
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a Javascript project or file with a few errors
   ![6errorindicator](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13930450/472c2c3c-ef5c-11e5-920e-5b3c5b305464.JPG)
2. Click the error/warning indicator at the bottom left (notice the error displayed count, mine says 6)
   ![6errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13930255/8cad0fd4-ef5b-11e5-99c2-f954125e67cd.JPG)
3. Click the error/warning indicator again. The command window shows up again. There are now only 5 errors shown in the window with a blank space at the bottom (where error 6 should be)
   ![5errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13930303/c64376ca-ef5b-11e5-9e95-ab6de156a499.JPG)
4. If you continue clicking the error/warning indicator the displayed errors will go down to only 2 showing (even though there are still 6 showing on the indicator) and empty space for the missing 4 bugs.
   ![2errors](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12900364/13930381/19ad1456-ef5c-11e5-97d7-aa1532e3d643.JPG)
5. If you click it again, it sometime cycles back to show all six but usually shows 5 with a blank space at the bottom.

data.title: "configure locale" is very technical
data.body:
Today I was trying to find the action to change the language and was just searching for "language" and could not find it. I am not sure if "Locale" is something a user would typically search for. On Mac OS at least the setting is called "Language and Region" and on Windows 10 "Language". 

I think we:
- should call it "Change Language"
- keep it english and not translate it

@dbaeumer fyi

data.title: Code will not start with locale='zh-cn' or locale='zh-tw'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Insiders, ef2a1fcaa553d14d7731b284a5ac5e4a55c42936
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Edit `locale.json`

``` json
{
    "locale":"zh-cn"
}
```
1. Restart VS Code

Result: It does not start, I just have a "Code - Insiders" menu with a Quit action.

You have to manually edit `locale.json` to get the tool to start again
